meta.subject: Geography
meta.source: SQA Higher Geography course specification and supplied glossary

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The proportion of the incident light or radiation that is reflected by a surface. Forests have a low albedo, whereas ice has a high albedo.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how albedo influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The layer of gases that surround the Earth consisting mainly of nitrogen and oxygen.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how atmosphere influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The variety of plant and animal life in the world or in a particular habitat.
cards.use: In an environment question, use biodiversity to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: This is a crack or fissure in the headland through which air and sea spray is expelled when waves break on the shore.
cards.use: Be able to define blowhole clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Thin, wispy clouds.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how cirrus influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: A dense, towering, vertical cloud associated with thunderstorms and atmospheric instability.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how cumulonimbus influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The anticlockwise rotation of the Earth which deflects winds to the right in the northern hemisphere and to the left in the southern hemisphere.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how coriolis effect influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: When materials erode at different speeds. This is due to one being more resistant than the other.
cards.use: In a differential erosion question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The combined process of evaporation and transpiration.
cards.use: Be able to define evapotranspiration clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Thermal energy generated and stored in the Earth.
cards.use: In an environment question, use geothermal energy to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The collective changes in the Earth’s movements. It is named after the Serbian geophysicist and astronomer Milutin Milanković.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how milankovitch cycles influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The ongoing decrease in ocean pH – it is caused by the uptake of CO₂ from the atmosphere.
cards.use: In an environment question, use ocean acidification to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Temporary phenomena on the sun – they are dark spots where the magnetic field is stronger than anywhere else on the sun.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how sunspots influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Before glaciations, valleys are made up of interlocking spurs that rivers meander around and form. A truncated spur forms when a glacier erodes the sides of a V-shaped valley, and cuts off the interlocking spurs. This leaves a steep ridge on the valley sides.
cards.use: Be able to define truncated spurs clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The belt of prevailing westerly winds in mid-latitudes in the southern hemisphere.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how westerlies influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Rock fragments (stones and pebbles) hit against each other and so are reduced in size.
cards.use: In a attrition question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: All the water on Earth, including oceans, rivers, lakes, groundwater, ice and water vapour.
cards.use: Be able to define hydrosphere clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The Earth’s rigid outer layer (crust and uppermost mantle).
cards.use: Be able to define lithosphere clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: All living things and the ecosystems they form.
cards.use: Be able to define biosphere clearly in one sentence.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The continuous movement of water between the atmosphere, land and oceans through processes such as evaporation and precipitation.
cards.use: In a hydrological cycle question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The area of land drained by a river and its tributaries.
cards.use: In a drainage basin question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Planning and managing land and water in a drainage basin to balance human needs and reduce impacts such as flooding and pollution.
cards.use: In a river basin management question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Energy from sources that are naturally replenished, such as wind, solar, hydro and geothermal.
cards.use: In an environment question, use renewable energy to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Energy from finite sources that will run out, such as coal, oil, gas and nuclear fuel.
cards.use: In an environment question, use non-renewable energy to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Using resources in a way that meets current needs while protecting the environment and opportunities for future generations.
cards.use: In an environment question, use sustainability to explain impacts and possible responses.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Long term changes in climate patterns, including temperature and precipitation, over decades or longer.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how climate change influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The day to day conditions of the atmosphere, such as temperature, precipitation and wind.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how weather influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Water that falls from the atmosphere to the Earth’s surface, such as rain, snow or hail.
cards.use: In a climate question, you might explain how precipitation influences weather or climate.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The wearing away and removal of rock or soil by moving water, wind or ice.
cards.use: In a erosion question, define it and then apply it to a named place.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The laying down of material transported by water, wind or ice.
cards.use: In a deposition question, define it and then apply it to a named place.
